hedline.hl1: Anti-Ross School Cartoon Picked the Wrong Target

abstract.p: Assn for a Better Long Island executive director Desmond Ryan letter holds Richard L Amper owes apology to students for mean-spirited cartoon on proposal to create educational institute on Ross School's East Hampton property (S)

block.p: For nearly a decade, the hired gun for Long Island's eco-radicals, Richard L. Amper Jr., has sought to vilify every developer who ever wanted to strengthen our economy. Now he seems to be on to far easier prey: our children [''Satire Campaign Gets Ross School's Goat,'' June 25].
Whatever the merits of a proposal by the Ross School to create an educational institute on their East Hampton property, the idea of putting students in the cross hairs of the debate is grotesque.

For nearly a decade, the hired gun for Long Island's eco-radicals, Richard L. Amper Jr., has sought to vilify every developer who ever wanted to strengthen our economy. Now he seems to be on to far easier prey: our children [''Satire Campaign Gets Ross School's Goat,'' June 25].
Whatever the merits of a proposal by the Ross School to create an educational institute on their East Hampton property, the idea of putting students in the cross hairs of the debate is grotesque.

It is no surprise that Mr. Amper, executive director of the Pine Barrens Society, was backed into a legal corner when he overreached with a misinformation campaign and had to issue a carefully worded apology.

His cartoon parody is the low-water mark of a society that seeks to attack personally anyone who disagrees with its agenda. For the students who were the target of his mean-spirited trick, Mr. Amper's apology will make a very good civics lesson in what happens when you combine cynicism and vitriol.
DESMOND RYAN Executive Director, Association for a Better Long Island Hauppauge
